H0.text: Amplitude is a sound wave characteristic that must be known when using sonar to measure distances underwater by sending a sound wave to a target and measuring the total time it takes for the wave to reach the target and then return to its source.

H1.text: Wavelength is the sound wave characteristic that must be known when using sonar to measure distances underwater by sending a sound wave to a target and measuring the total time it takes to reach the target and return to its source.

H2.text: Frequency is the sound wave characteristic that must be known when using sonar to measure distances underwater by sending a sound wave to a target and measuring the total time it takes for the wave to reach the target and return to its source.

H3.text: Speed is the sound wave characteristic that must be known when using sonar to measure distances underwater by sending a sound wave to a target and measuring the total time it takes for the wave to reach the target and return to its source.

A4.text: In salt water that is free of air bubbles and suspended sediment, sound travels at about 1500 m/s.

A5.text: The speed of sound in seawater depends on pressure (hence depth), temperature (a change of 1 °C ~ 4 m/s), and salinity (a change of 1‰ ~ 1 m/s), and empirical equations have been derived to accurately calculate the speed of sound from these variables.
